metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C++ Structures (struct)
C++ Structures
Structures (also called structs) are a way to group several related variables into one place.
content.html: Structures (also called structs) are a way to group several related variables into one place.

content.text: Each variable in the structure is known as a member of the structure.
content.html: Each variable in the structure is known as a member of the structure.

content.text: Unlike an array , a structure can contain many different data types: int , string , bool , etc.
content.html: Unlike an array, a structure can contain many different data types: int, string, bool, etc.

content.text: Create a Structure
To create a structure, use the struct keyword and declare each of its members inside curly braces.
content.html: To create a structure, use the struct keyword and declare each of its members inside curly braces.

content.text: After the declaration, specify the name of the structure variable ( myStructure in the example below):
content.html: After the declaration, specify the name of the structure variable (myStructure in the example below):

content.code_html:
struct {             // Structure declaration
  int myNum;         // Member (int variable)
  string myString;   // Member (string variable)
} myStructure;       // Structure variable

content.text: Access Structure Members
To access members of a structure, use the dot syntax ( . ):
content.html: To access members of a structure, use the dot syntax (.):

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a structure variable called myStructure
// Assign values to members of myStructure

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a structure variable called myStructure
// Assign values to members of myStructure

content.code_html:
// Create a structure variable called myStructure
struct {
  int myNum;
  string myString;
} myStructure;

// Assign values to members of myStructure
 myStructure.myNum = 1;
myStructure.myString = "Hello World!";

// Print members of myStructure
 cout << myStructure.myNum << "\n";
cout << myStructure.myString << "\n";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a structure variable called myStructure
// Assign values to members of myStructure

content.text: One Structure in Multiple Variables
You can use a comma ( , ) to use one structure in many variables:
content.html: You can use a comma (,) to use one structure in many variables:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Multiple structure variables separated with commas

syntax_highlighting.text: // Multiple structure variables separated with commas

content.code_html:
struct {
  int myNum;
  string myString;
} myStruct1, myStruct2, myStruct3; // Multiple structure variables separated with commas

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Multiple structure variables separated with commas

content.text: This example shows how to use a structure in two different variables:
content.html: This example shows how to use a structure in two different variables:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // We can add variables by separating them with a comma here
// Put data into the first structure
// Put data into the second structure

syntax_highlighting.text: // We can add variables by separating them with a comma here
// Put data into the first structure
// Put data into the second structure

content.code_html:
struct {
  string brand;
  string model;
  int year;
} myCar1, myCar2; // We can add variables by separating them with a comma here
// Put data into the first structure
 myCar1.brand = "BMW";
myCar1.model = "X5";
myCar1.year = 1999;

// Put data into the second structure
 myCar2.brand = "Ford";
myCar2.model = "Mustang";
myCar2.year = 1969;

// Print the structure members
 cout << myCar1.brand << " " << myCar1.model << " " << myCar1.year << "\n";
cout << myCar2.brand << " " << myCar2.model << " " << myCar2.year << "\n";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // We can add variables by separating them with a comma here
// Put data into the first structure
// Put data into the second structure

content.text: Named Structures
By giving a name to the structure, you can treat it as a data type. This means that you can create variables with this structure anywhere in the program at any time.
content.html: By giving a name to the structure, you can treat it as a data type. This means that you can create variables with this structure anywhere in the program at any time.

content.text: To create a named structure, put the name of the structure right after the struct keyword:
content.html: To create a named structure, put the name of the structure right after the struct keyword:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
struct car {  // This structure is now named "car"  string 
  brand;  string model;  int year;};

content.code:
struct car {  // This structure is now named "car"  string
brand;  string model;  int year;};

syntax_highlighting.text:
struct car {  // This structure is now named "car"  string 
  brand;  string model;  int year;};

content.code_html:
struct car {  // This structure is now named "car"
  string brand;
  string model;
  int year;
};

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
struct car {  // This structure is now named "car"  string 
  brand;  string model;  int year;};

content.text: To declare a variable that uses the structure, use the name of the structure as the data type of the variable:
content.html: To declare a variable that uses the structure, use the name of the structure as the data type of the variable:

content.code_html: car myCar1;

content.text: Now the structure can be reused anywhere by using car as the data type:
content.html: Now the structure can be reused anywhere by using car as the data type:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a car structure and store it in myCar1;
// Create another car structure and store it in myCar2;

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a car structure and store it in myCar1;
// Create another car structure and store it in myCar2;

content.code_html:
// Declare a structure named "car"
 struct car {
  string brand;
  string model;
  int year;
};

int main() {
  // Create a car structure and store it in myCar1;
   car myCar1;
  myCar1.brand = "BMW";
  myCar1.model = "X5";
  myCar1.year = 1999;

  // Create another car structure and store it in myCar2;
   car myCar2;
  myCar2.brand = "Ford";
  myCar2.model = "Mustang";
  myCar2.year = 1969;
 
  // Print the structure members
   cout << myCar1.brand << " " << myCar1.model << " " << myCar1.year << "\n";
  cout << myCar2.brand << " " << myCar2.model << " " << myCar2.year << "\n";
 
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a car structure and store it in myCar1;
// Create another car structure and store it in myCar2;

content.text: Challenge Task
Create a structure to represent a student. It should have the following members:
content.html: Create a structure to represent a student. It should have the following members:

content.text: Then:

content.code_html:
Name: Liam
Age: 35
Grade: A

content.text: Solution

content.code_html:
#include <iostream>
#include <string>
using namespace std;

struct student {
  string name;
  int age;
  char grade;
};

int main() {
  student s1;

  s1.name = "John";
  s1.age = 35;
  s1.grade = 'A';

  cout << "Name: " << s1.name << "\n";
  cout << "Age: " << s1.age << "\n";
  cout << "Grade: " << s1.grade << "\n";

  return 0;
}

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is a structure (or struct) in C++?
content.html: What is a structure (or struct) in C++?

metadata.question: What is a structure (or struct) in C++?

options.text: A way to group related variables of different data types
A data type that stores only strings
